content.title: Madrigal, just like home

introduction.small: Inspired by the concept of a room in a private home, a Havana film enthusiast opened a bar in the heart of his house. Unique experience guaranteed.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Madrigal, just like home

paragraphs.text:
In a renovated old building with typical 20th-century Cuban architecture, Rafael Rosales is driven. This film director has successfully turned his home into a trendy bar. Madrigal is the name of a feature film in which he participated. In Havana, his establishment is one of the symbols of "New Cuba" with its arty appearance, apparent brick walls in brown, ochre and black tones, wide ebony piano and "political" paintings. The famous figure Che, omnipresent, chaperones the patrons. The guerrilla, Tania, only woman to fight with the revolutionary, is also represented above the counter.
Rafael Rosales opens a few rooms of his house to visitors. Choose one of the homemade cocktails from among a small quality selection and have a seat at the enormous wooden table reigning in the dining room or favour the intimacy of the living room and its comfortable sofas. During summer evenings, take your quarters on the terrace, like a real local.

Madrigal
Calle 17 n° 809
La Habana
+53 7 8312433

madrigalbarcafe.wordpress.com

Drinks: from 5 CUC

content.title: El Del Frente, tapas and cocktails in secret

introduction.small: The hip youth of Havana has established their HQ at El Del Frente restaurant and bar. Join their ranks to enjoy a festive evening in the heart of the old city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: El Del Frente, tapas and cocktails in secret

paragraphs.text:
Havana is full of secret places but El Del Frente will soon have none for you. Located just across from the brewery of their older brother O'Reilly 304, the establishment carries the same friendly and dynamic spirit. Try exquisite artisanal cocktails, served in a mason jar that will remind of you home and make you feel at ease. Aficionados of local culinary experiences can also try the lobster risotto or octopus served with sweet potatoes with paprika oil. For small groups, some tapas to share will be offered. These copious and colourful dishes combine flavours to perfection.
Take a stroll on the rooftop for dinner at sunset or simply enjoy the view overlooking the city, one of Havana's best mojitos in hand – to be consumed in moderation. Immortalise this moment and panorama that will take your breath away, but not your appetite.

El Del Frente

content.title: Soroa, in the heart of Cuban nature

introduction.small: One hour west of Havana lies the charming village of Soroa in a lush natural setting, in the province of Pinar del Río.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Soroa, in the heart of Cuban nature

paragraphs.text:
Riddled with mountains and valleys, the Pinar del Río region lies just 100 kilometres from Havana. Enjoy hikes in the surrounding nature, an opportunity to take in a breath of fresh air. Soroa is an excellent starting point for your expedition in the region. First visit the orchid garden – El Oquidiario – which has made the village famous. Here you can discover more than 700 species of orchids from all over the world, only some of which are endemic to the island. Since flowering takes place around November, the best time to visit is in the ensuing weeks.

After the garden, go on an adventure around the village, climbing up the Mirador, a hill that rises up to 250 metres and from which you will enjoy a wonderful view of the region.

Finally, you will have to venture off to find the del Arco Iris waterfall, a magnificent 20-metre waterfall from where you will almost certainly see a rainbow.

Soroa

content.title: A family outing to the Acuario Nacional de Cuba

introduction.small: Spend a pleasant day at the National Aquarium of Cuba where you can spend hours contemplating all kinds of marine life.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A family outing to the Acuario Nacional de Cuba

paragraphs.text:
The National Aquarium of Cuba opened its doors in 1960. Since then, this scientific centre has taken the greatest care of marine fauna and flora with the aim of educating and raising awareness among the general public. Discover an amazing variety of fish, sea lions and dolphins, all in a vast area where children can play educational games.

You can attend shows featuring marine mammals as well as exhibitions on underwater caves, the Mangrove Trail with its many species, and see the main aquatic landscapes of Cuba that are presented in six aquariums. Don't miss the tropical islands where you can see different specimens of turtles such as the Caguama, Carey or Green Tortoise, or Florida pelicans in a reconstitution of their natural habitat. Renovated in 2002, this is one of the most beautiful aquariums in the Caribbean.

content.title: Siá Kará Café, a bit of gourmet exoticism

introduction.small: Hidden behind the Capitol building, the Siá Kará Café brings together Cubans and tourists from all over the world around large plates, all in the utmost conviviality.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Siá Kará Café, a bit of gourmet exoticism

paragraphs.text:
Originally from Basque country, Mathieu Royer manages his café-bistro in a French spirit of sharing and celebration. As he welcomes you with open arms, you will discover the funky decor: ties hang on the wall by the dozens, there are white chandeliers, a singular choice of photos and paintings. The heteroclite decoration gives it a unique charm appreciated by locals and travellers from all over.

For your evening out, treat yourself to a lobster or some fresh prawns, plantain chips (tostones) or a tasty ceviche. And if you are in the mood to dance all night, enjoy the bar stocked with rums, cognacs, wines, whiskeys, beers and quality cocktails. Expect the Siá Kará Café to make you fall in love with one of the most beautiful cities in Cuba.

content.title: Casa Abel, cuisine and cigars

introduction.small: For a typically Cuban evening, head to Casa Abel, where you can have the most authentic meals with suggestions on how to choose your ‘Habano'.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Casa Abel, cuisine and cigars

paragraphs.text:
This small restaurant is run by the colourful Abel Expósito Diaz, who has only one goal: for you to feel at home. If you have the slightest doubt about the origin or quality of a cigar, Abel can tell you what you need to know. You can follow his advice with your eyes closed as he had a long career at Partagás, the famous Cuban cigar maker.

After having spent years talking cigars with visitors, Abel decided to welcome them to his home and today has a convivial restaurant that serves typical Cuban cuisine. The chef is particularly proud of his grilled lobster, he claims it to be the best in Cuba and so do his customers. Also try the fresh salad or the shrimp risotto. After dinner, the owner will invite you upstairs to a small smoking room to have an authentic cigar that he will have selected for you with a fresh mojito. After all, it is the tradition.

content.title: Villa Flora, for a stay among friends

introduction.small: In the residential neighbourhood of Miramar in Havana, the Villa Flora Inn and its seven suites offer a perfect setting for a Cuban stay with friends.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Villa Flora, for a stay among friends

paragraphs.text:
Villa Flora hides behind Cuba's lush vegetation a few blocks from the sea. Once in the garden, you will discover a beautiful white colonial style house. Nidia will welcome you with a sincere smile on her face. She is in charge and will make your stay delightful.

For your holidays with friends or family, the seven suites are ideal for everyone to preserve their privacy. Bright and in white tones, the suites are decorated with wooden furniture, and have authentic floor tiles with marble in the bathrooms.

Outside, the pool will cool you off at the end of the day, and you can sunbathe in one of the deckchairs or hammocks scattered in the garden. Sports fans can challenge each other on the squash court, while others will sit in the shade of the patio to have a drink or to read. There is a three-night minimum stay, which gives you time to discover the hidden pearls of the capital, just a few minutes away on foot.

content.title: A detour by the Cathedral of the Virgin Mary of the Immaculate Conception

introduction.small: Havana Cathedral has stood proudly in the heart of La Habana Vieja district since its construction by the Jesuits in 1748.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A detour by the Cathedral of the Virgin Mary of the Immaculate Conception

paragraphs.text:
On the Plaza de la Catedral, you will discover a Cuban architectural treasure. Designed by the Italian architect Francesco Borromini, its baroque facade with a greyish hue makes you think of an old postcard. Framed by two asymmetrical spires, the cathedral is also known as ‘San Cristóbal' in honour of Christopher Columbus, whose funerary monument was lodged here for many years before being repatriated to Seville. Alejo Carpentier, a 20th-century Cuban writer, poetically described the building as ‘music cut out of stone'.

Classified as a UNESCO World Heritage site since 1982, the cathedral is particularly popular with tourists who come to admire one of the oldest cathedrals in the Americas. The interior of the building, soberly decorated in a neoclassical style, contains a Carrara marble altar inlaid with gold, silver and onyx. On the evening of 31 December, the bells ring throughout the city.

Catedral de la Virgen María de la Concepción Inmaculada (Catedral San Cristobal de La Habana)

content.title: Casa Chez Nous, a Cuban bed and breakfast

introduction.small: Casa Chez Nous represents the authenticity of a Cuban-style family home with a colonial style and an incredible charm.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Casa Chez Nous, a Cuban bed and breakfast

paragraphs.text:
At the Casa Chez Nous, you will think of the saying: ‘Mi casa es tu casa'. In a beautiful colonial structure built in the early 1900s, the Casa Chez Nous is a peaceful place, only a few streets away from the famous Plaza Vieja. Gustavo, the owner, is a well-known personality in Havana. A radio host, he knows everything about his city and its residents, so make sure you ask for his recommendations, he will be pleased to share his favourites with you.

Inside, there are two immense rooms with a typically Cuban atmosphere with colonial furniture, coloured walls, the indispensable fans, and a lovely shaded courtyard with trees. You can have your breakfast on the ground floor in the large salon or on the shaded patio on the roof. With Buena Vista Social Club playing in the background, you can live to the rhythm of Havana. If you prefer an Art deco style, Gustavo also has a room in the building right across the street with a decor that is a bit more modern but still just as authentic.

Casa Chez Nous

content.title: Gran Hotel Manzana, in the heart of Old Town Havana

introduction.small: This 5-star hotel aims to please with a rooftop pool, exceptional spa and stylish contemporary rooms.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Gran Hotel Manzana, in the heart of Old Town Havana

paragraphs.text:
In the heart of Old Town Havana, the Gran Hotel Manzana welcomes you to a world of luxury and comfort. The hotel, part of the Kempinski Hotels group, perfectly combines contemporary decor and period furniture. With high ceilings and large windows, the sun comes in naturally to brighten the rooms. The white and grey tones are accented by a touch of colour – purple, turquoise, or burgundy, depending on the room.

The rooftop is the ideal place to relax at the end of the day at the bar or in the pool while admiring the panorama of Old Town, the Capitol and the Grand Theatre.

Take a relaxing break at the spa on the sixth floor of the hotel. The expert hands of the beauticians will perform relaxing or energizing massages or revitalizing scrubs.

content.title: Hotel Telegrafo - a gentle return to the early 20th century

introduction.small: Formerly the best address in Latin America, this hotel with classic architecture retains the quaintness of the past while flirting with modernity. Ideal for visiting Havana.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel Telegrafo - a gentle return to the early 20th century

paragraphs.text:
Go back in time and imagine the late 19th century when this hotel opened at the foot of the old town, at the corner of Prado and Neptuno streets. Totally renovated in 1911, this blue tapestried establishment was long considered the most modern in the city and one of the best hotels in Latin America.

A few minutes walk from the Museo de Bellas Artes, the Capitolio and Gran Teatro de La Habana, the Telegrafo is a haven of peace in the always lively neighbourhood. The inner courtyard, nestled under the original red brick vaults and with a section of wall in colourful ceramics exemplifies the colonial architecture of Havana. Have a drink at the bar or breakfast served buffet-style. The high-ceilinged rooms are bright and spacious.

content.title: Esto No Es Un Café, where art begins at the table

introduction.small: All beautiful, all new, this handkerchief of a restaurant tucked in the old town combines charm, art, history and delights.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Esto No Es Un Café, where art begins at the table

paragraphs.text:
In the Callejon del Chorro and just around the corner from the San Cristobal de La Habana cathedral, this small restaurant stands out, the only one of this narrow street, right up against a stone screen-printing workshop.

Owner Mayrelis Peraza named the place in tribute to Magritte. Her passion for modern art finds its way in the decoration and onto the menu: Pollock chicken, Broodthaers casserole of lamb… Behind these prestigious names, Cuban specialities are being skillfully revisited, like the ropa vieja, a meat-based dish, and among the very best in town. For dessert, go for the chocolate fondant cake, to die for.

After this food break, climb upstairs to a gallery that showcases the work of upcoming artists, then follow the sound of salsa music towards the terrace, where you will enjoy a mojito or a freshly squeezed juice. Musicians regularly perform there. A joyful and inviting address, not to be passed by.

content.title: La Habana Vieja: the historical heart of the city

introduction.small: No visit to Havana is complete without getting lost in Old Havana. Monuments, museums, and buildings: every step one takes in its streets reveals something wonderful.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Habana Vieja: the historical heart of the city

paragraphs.text:
The beating heart of the Cuban capital, the Habana Vieja district covers five kilometres and encompasses the historic centre of the city. A UNESCO World Heritage Site, it was founded by the Spanish in 1519. A drop zone for settlers and gold miners, protected by the Morro Castle and the Castillo de la Real Fuerza, by the 18th century it had grown to a large population.

Still as lively as ever, the neighbourhood of Habana Vieja is a must: stroll through its streets admiring its Baroque and Neoclassical buildings, cool off in the shade of the columns of the Plaza de Armas, or enjoy an evening gala at the Gran Teatro de La Habana.

The area also contains some of the most beautiful religious buildings in the city, such as the Baroque Havana Cathedral of San Cristóbal or the basilica and the monastery of San Francisco de Asis.

content.title: Le Malecón: a salty promenade

introduction.small: Hammered by waves, this long esplanade has a rich architectural heritage and is an emblematic landmark of Havana.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Malecón: a salty promenade

paragraphs.text:
The Malecón is the best place to take the pulse of the capital. Tourists and Habaneros converge on this seaside esplanade built in the early 1980s to allow the middle classes to enjoy the benefits of sea air along a wide boulevard.

The following decades saw the prodigious expansion of the esplanade, which became the favourite cruising strip for the city's fleet of vintage Chevrolets, Cadillacs, and Buicks. The eight-kilometre stretch possesses a number of Art Nouveau and Neoclassical architectural gems. Elegant retro street lights were recently installed as part of the city's efforts to restore the Malecón to its former splendour.

In the spring and during storms, the sight of giant waves crashing against the seawall is spectacular. Even on calmer days, walkers can get hit with a refreshing splash.

content.title: The Museum of the City: all the magnificence of Havana

introduction.small: This splendid palace was scene to some of the Cuban capital's finest hours.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Museum of the City: all the magnificence of Havana

paragraphs.text:
You will find a white marble patio, very typical of Havana. At the centre is an impressive marble statue of Christopher Columbus, with live peacocks strutting around at his feet. And this is only the beginning of a visit to the Palacio de los Capitanes Generales.

This museum, one of the most exciting in the city, was built in the 1790s, in a dazzling Baroque style. The first residence of the Spanish governors of the island, it later housed American military governors, and then, in the early 20th century, the President of the Republic. Bequeathed to the city in 1920, the palace was transformed into a town hall and a municipal museum. It has a spectacular collection of antique furniture, a gorgeous 19th-century carriage, plus the magnificent art collections of many of the city's notables and governors, as well as documents tracing the city's colourful history.

Museo de la Ciudad
Calle Tacón
Plaza de Armas
Habana Vieja
10100 La Habana

content.title: Centro Cultural Antiguos Almacenes: an arty market

introduction.small: Located in an old warehouse, this great local craft market is the best place for souvenirs in all of Cuba.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Centro Cultural Antiguos Almacenes: an arty market

paragraphs.text:
It is possible, in Havana, to find typical Cuban souvenirs without the usual crassness and kitsch.

The Centro Cultural Antiguos Almacenes de Depósito San José is a giant craft market offering the most iconic objects of Havana: garish-coloured paintings by local artists, guayaberas (short-sleeve, open-neck Cuban shirts), sculptures, leather, jewellery, and various trinkets and gadgets bearing the image of Che Guevara The souvenirs here are of high quality, which is why you will see as many locals as tourists among the shoppers.

The metal-framed structure itself, an old, fully renovated maritime warehouse, very retro and Art Deco, is worth the trip in itself.

Centro cultural Antiguos Almacenes
Avenida del Puerto
Habana Vieja
10100 La Habana

content.title: Partagás: mythical rolled cigars

introduction.small: Cigar aficionados shouldn't miss the opportunity to visit this famous factory and learn the intricacies of its production.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Partagás: mythical rolled cigars

paragraphs.text:
Only in our collective imagination is Cuba still enveloped in cigar smoke. Even Fidel has given them up. Yet it would be a shame to miss out on a close look at this jewel of craftsmanship during your stay.

Never buy a cigar in the street, go instead to Partagás, one of the oldest factories in Cuba, where Mille Fleurs, Presidentes, and Coronas are rolled by the expert fingers of hundreds of workers. (Unfortunately, the very long Visible Inmenso, created for Che Guevera after his doctor restricted him to one smoke a day, is no longer available).

Founded by the Spaniard Jaime Partagás in 1845, the factory is the best known and most reliable in Havana. Serious enthusiasts also visit the Tobacco Museum (Mercaderes No. 120).

La Real Fábrica de Tabacos Partagás

content.title: La Divina Pastora: a surprise by the sea

introduction.small: This ideally located restaurant offers innovative traditional cuisine and excellent ingredients.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Divina Pastora: a surprise by the sea

paragraphs.text:
Located next to the sea and the Dársena de los Franceses, this small restaurant has a sublime view of the Bay of Havana, a few metres from an 18th-century cannon battery that once defended the El Morro fortress. Its view of the horizon and some of the capital's most popular monuments sets a high bar for a restaurant that also has stout culinary ambitions.

La Divina Pastora is adept at reinventing traditional dishes with astonishing spices, velvety textures, and an always-artful presentation that showcases high-quality produce. Opt for seafood and extraordinary fresh fish, you can choose your lobster from one of the restaurant's tanks. La Divina Pastora also boasts perfect service and an enticing wine list.

La Divina Pastora

content.title: Kilometro Zero: Havana rocks!

introduction.small: Located in the heart of the old town, this traditional bar mixes delicious cocktails, typical cuisine, and a crazy atmosphere.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Kilometro Zero: Havana rocks!

paragraphs.text:
White tiles, wooden chairs, simple tables, and a bare stone countertop: welcome to Kilometro Zero, a typical Cuban restaurant and bar rendered somewhat modern by graffiti and black leather sofas which is very popular among Cubans, and very, very friendly.

By day it is a casual, convivial hangout place, where classic Cuban hits play nonstop. People come for a coffee, a refreshing drink, or something to eat: go for the seafood stew, prepared with the catch of the day, and known for its octopus, one of the most tender and succulent in the city.

At night, the place totally rocks out: local bands perform on the small stage, and colourful cocktails line the bar.

content.title: Las Terrazas: a nature lover's paradise near Havana

introduction.small: Not far from the capital lies a small village in the heart of a nature preserve.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Las Terrazas: a nature lover's paradise near Havana

paragraphs.text:
Tempted by eco-tourism? Try the pioneer village of Las Terrazas in the UNESCO classified nature reserve of Sierra Del Rosario, about 50 kilometres from Havana.

Built on the ruins of a coffee plantation, it is home to more than 800 protected plants and 70 endangered species of birds. Founded in 1968 by a handful of Cubans anxious about the ravages of deforestation, the village of whitewashed houses circling a beautiful lake is a model of sustainable development and environmental preservation. It has a number of craft shops and small restaurants serving local organic dishes.

A great green getaway, it is perfect for exploring the flora and fauna of Cuba, while spending a relaxing day far from the bustle of the city.

Candelaria

content.title: Museum of Fine Arts: the world in two palaces

introduction.small: Two buildings are necessary to display and view the city's rich collection of art, and it'll take you at least a day to wander through it all.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Museum of Fine Arts: the world in two palaces

paragraphs.text:
The pavilion devoted to national artistic creation is in the middle of a beautiful garden with a lovely collection of sculptures. This part of the Bellas Artes museum provides a chronological presentation of paintings, prints, installations, and drawings by Cuban artists of the last five centuries.

Big names from the colonial era, such as Víctor Patricio and Vincente Escobar, are alongside Cuban academic artists such as Armando Menocal and contemporaries like Nelson Dominguez and José Bedia Valdés.

A few steps away, the three-level, 18,000-square-metre Palacio de Bellas Artes Universel presents an extensive collection of foreign art. The permanent collection includes European pieces side by side with Latin American works and precious finds from Ancient Greece, Egypt, and Rome. The museum's temporary exhibitions are often of the highest calibre.

content.title: The Havana-Club Museum: distilled secrets

introduction.small: An essential stop for rum lovers, and anyone curious about Cuban culture.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Havana-Club Museum: distilled secrets

paragraphs.text:
If you visit Havana, you will no doubt succumb to the temptation of a delicious mojito. Did you know that rum, the main ingredient of this famous cocktail, comes from sugar cane? Do you know how it is harvested, and have you ever seen the white oak barrels in which the liquor is aged?

From the cane fields to the famous Havana Club bottles, this fine rum museum, located in a historic building in the heart of Habana Vieja, introduces you to the mysteries of the most emblematic alcohol of the West Indies.

The very educational guided tour gives details about rum's origins and manufacturing process. The culture of rum, since the darkest days of slavery through to the development of international trade and the advent of the steam train, is intimately linked to the history of Cuba. The tour ends with a tasting (to be enjoyed in moderation). As they say in the toast to Havana: salud!

content.title: The Tropicana: party under the stars

introduction.small: Joyous sensuality and kitsch combine in this institution dating from 1939, a survivor of the revolution.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Tropicana: party under the stars

paragraphs.text:
Imagine a flood of feathers, a profusion of glitter, frenzied dancers, and heady music, all under starry skies in the middle of lush tropical gardens.

The Tropicana club and cabaret opened on 1 January 1939. The biggest stars in show business performed here, from Josephine Baker to Nat King Cole. In the 1950s it was also a casino: gamblers placed bets under the Crystal Arch, a stunning glass ceiling covering the players without depriving them of the spectacular view of the sky.

An iconic place of Cuban music and culture, the Tropicana proposes outdoor soirées, where you will savour, in addition to the delicious cocktails, the exuberance of the rhythms, the splendour of the costumes, and the magic of the colours.

Tropicana
Calle 72 A
11500 Marianao

content.title: Cuba is a cool-car heaven

introduction.small: There are more gorgeous old Buicks and Cadillacs per square inch of roadway in Havana than anywhere else in the world; it's a vintage-car-lover's paradise.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cuba is a cool-car heaven

paragraphs.text:
It is impossible to imagine Havana without its dazzling fleet of colourful old Pontiacs, Thunderbirds, Ford Model Ts, and other vintage masterworks of the American dream. To celebrate these beautiful machines, a little-known and surprising museum has been opened on Calle Oficios. Some of the city's best-preserved models are inside. But the city itself is a vast open-air museum, and the best way to see these well-kept relics of a bygone era is out on the streets, where they have a little rust, a few dents, and maybe a few jerry-rigged fixes (original parts are expensive and scarce).

Many owners use their almendrones as taxis, which is great way to see the sights, or you can book a tour with a driver in a convertible.

Regrettably—for now, at least, unless you do so illegally—you can't rent one and take it on your own tour of the island, with you behind the wheel.

content.title: Museum of the Revolution: hasta la victoria!

introduction.small: In this city haunted by the figure of Che, make sure to take in the rich historical collections in this spectacular palace.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Museum of the Revolution: hasta la victoria!

paragraphs.text:
The Soviet SU-100 tank on the lawn, used by Fidel Castro at the Bay of Pigs in 1961, sets the tone. It contrasts nicely with the spacious pomp of this former presidential palace, designed by Paul Belau and Carlos Maruri.

Fulgencio Batista had barely been deposed when the building (where the former dictator narrowly escaped an assassination attempt) was requisitioned to sing the praises of the revolution. It chronologically presents the struggle of the Cuban people for their freedom. From the pre-Columbian culture to the current regime, you will cross the figures of Che and Castro among other propaganda materials, historical landmarks, and iconic pieces like the Granma, the boat that brought the rebels from Tuxpán (Mexico).

If the intricacies of modern history leave you cold, take a look at the interior design by Tiffany and the Salón de los Espejos, inspired by Versailles' Hall of Mirrors.

Museo de la Revolución
Calle Refugio n° 1
Centro Habana
10600 La Habana

content.title: The “Casas particulares”, for a truly authentic night

introduction.small: Jewels of Cuban culture as important as cigars or rum, these homestays are of cultural and economic interest.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The “Casas particulares”, for a truly authentic night

paragraphs.text:
Look for signs with a blue arrow on a white background that say Arrendador divisa. These indicate that the owners of the house host overnight guests. Professionalization is such that some welcomes can be a bit cold and remote, but sometimes you'll be received warmly, as if you were a long-lost cousin arriving for a family reunion.

Sites like www.casaparticular.com offer various places and other agencies are starting to make inroads on the island, but the Internet is still pretty shaky in Cuba. Local contacts are often the most effective: if an owner can't take you in, the chances are that he or she will know someone who can. You can also try to line up something before your arrival by contacting Fabio and Eugenio at Greenhouse or the Casa of Pepe y Rafaela but word of mouth is such that their rooms in Old Havana are usually fully booked.

Rooms: from 30 CUC

content.title: The Café Arcangel: divinely sweet

introduction.small: Far from the heated Cuban rhythms, the Arcangel offers a cosy coffee break accompanied by delicious pastries.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Café Arcangel: divinely sweet

paragraphs.text:
The Café Arcangel does offer some good cocktails on its menu (this is Cuba after all), but save that experience for one of the town's exciting rum bars. Come here instead to relax over a cup of their delicious mocha or an elegant café Viennois. If you have a sweet tooth, go for one their traditional tortas (cakes), famous throughout the city. Or maybe try a nice sandwich and salad. Behind its brightly coloured facade, typical of Habana Vieja, you will especially enjoy the café's traditional cachet: mosaic tables and wrought iron, old photographs, and Charlie Chaplin films screened on the wall.

In a cosy atmosphere that isn't at all stuffy, with soft, sweet music playing in the background, you'll find this a great place to unwind after a long walk in the bustling streets—and the perfect spot to ready yourself for the long night of bar hopping ahead.

content.title: Fábrica del Arte Cubano: the cultural revolution

introduction.small: A centre of multidisciplinary art, design, and architecture, the FAC is an intensely active player on the Cuban and international creative scene.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Fábrica del Arte Cubano: the cultural revolution

paragraphs.text:
Do you love good art, music, theatre, architecture, photography, industrial design, graphic arts, and cinema, and want it all at once, served up in a cutting-edge space? Then head straight to the Fábrica, the newest trend sensation in Havana. Open from Thursday to Sunday, it is the vibrational centre of everything hip and happening in Cuba. The founder of this exceptional space is the hip-hop musician X Alfonso, an adept of African-Cuban rhythms who has created an eclectic blend here of live concerts, art exhibitions, screenings, theatre, dance, debates, and more. He likes to wander the halls of this first-class UFO and engage with visitors. Set in a former factory in the vibrant neighbourhood of Vedado, the Fábrica del Arte Cubano (FAC for short) also has a comfy bar where you can hang out and drink reasonably priced coffee and cocktails.

content.title: Habana 1791: the soul of Cuba in a bottle

introduction.small: Immerse yourself in the scents of Cuba at this luxurious and exclusive address.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Habana 1791: the soul of Cuba in a bottle

paragraphs.text:
Founded in 2000 by the Cuban perfumer Yanelda Mendosa, this little shop in an 18th-century house in Old Havana has become an absolute must for lovers of beautiful scents. Trained in the French perfume capital of Grasse, Mendosa's creations are inspired by the olfactory ambience of colonial Cuba: colognes, lavender, violet, tobacco, coffee, and leather.

La Habana 1791 makes 20 perfumes from flowers grown on the island, decanted in sublime bottles created by the virtuosos of the ACAA (Cuban Association of Craftsmen Artists).

Her star perfume, Habanera, is very sensual and feminine. She creates custom perfumes to match your tastes and personality, and her shop sells jewellery by the Congregation of San Eloy Goldsmiths.

content.title: El Cocinero

introduction.small: Industrial decor, artistic melting pot, and grid-patterned dishware are the ingredients for success at this extraordinarily trendy address.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: El Cocinero

paragraphs.text:
A former oil factory (its giant brick fireplace is still in place) next to the equally popular Fábrica de Arte Cubano, El Cocinero attracts hipsters on the lookout for the next new trend.

The hard-to-get dining tables are at the top of a long flight of stairs. Choose the pleasantly breezy lounge terrace or stay inside where it is cosy. The industrial architecture creates a relaxed but stylish atmosphere.

Foodies flock to this restaurant, which opened in 2013, because of the good music, sophisticated cocktails, and cuisine that blends the flavours of local produce with culinary traditions from around the world (Cuban lamb with Indian influences, duck with bitter Caribbean orange…).

content.title: Coppelia: the movie star

introduction.small: One of the largest ice-cream parlours in the world and the star of the hit movie ‘Strawberry and Chocolate', Coppelia is a Havana institution.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Coppelia: the movie star

paragraphs.text:
Looking like a flying saucer in the middle of a park, Coppelia is a kind of national monument. In 1993, the popularity of this ice-cream parlour, which was founded in 1966, exploded because of the release of Strawberry and Chocolate and the avalanche of nominations the film garnered.

The decor of Coppelia is indeed closely linked to the relationship forged between marginal Diego and communist activist David in the movie. Alas, it is a long time since the menu of the house had 26 mostly original flavours.

Now there is usually only two or three, but the queues are still just as long: Coppelia's chain of parlours dishes up 16,000 litres of ice cream to 35,000 customers every day!

content.title: Hotel Capri: the repentant gangster

introduction.small: The hotel's sulphurous past amuses and titillates guests, but the organisation and service are the real attractions.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel Capri: the repentant gangster

paragraphs.text:
Recently renovated from floor to ceiling after being closed for a decade, the infamous Capri, located in the heart of the Vedado district, is now fully reborn. Its 250 rooms have been miraculously transformed into streamlined showcases of modern design, but the most obvious change here is in the clientele.

The American actor George Raft (best known for Scarface) inaugurated the Capri when it opened in 1957. Behind this smokescreen could be seen Charley ‘The Blade,' Sonny ‘The Butcher' and other members of the Santo Trafficante Jr. mob, who financed the place and ran its casino.

During the revolution, this place of perdition became a hostel for soldiers. Scenes from The Godfather II would have been shot here if Coppola could have got authorization; instead he had to make do with the Dominican Republic. Cinephiles will recognize, however, at the top of modernist building, the glamorous pool from the opening scene of Soy Cuba. Others will just enjoy the dazzling view of the city.

content.title: Agromercado: the taste of Cuba

introduction.small: The best food products from the island are sold directly by producers in this very inviting farmer's market.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Agromercado: the taste of Cuba

paragraphs.text:
Farmland occupies a third of the island, and one Cuban in five works in agriculture.

To discover and taste Cuba's rich array of local production, visit one of Havana's many agromercados. Commonly known as “agro”, these are covered or open street markets offering wonderful displays of fresh produce at low prices. The one at the intersection of Calle 19 and A specialises in rare produce and fresh herbs. To taste the paradoxes of Cuban society, go to the neighbourhood of Nuevo Vedado, in the vicinity of Calle Tulipan.

Three markets coexist here: one is 100% state-run and sells its goods at very low prices. Its neighbour offers similar products but is run by the Communist Youth organisation. The third, private, has more produce and a cafeteria.

content.title: La Bodeguita del Medio: a sprightly septuagenarian

introduction.small: Mother of the mojito and Papa Hemingway's favourite watering hole, La Bodeguita is probably more visited than the great museums of Havana.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Bodeguita del Medio: a sprightly septuagenarian

paragraphs.text:
People make the pilgrimage to this bar for two reasons: because they're mojito fans and want to try one in the place it was invented back in the 1940s, or they're Hemingway junkies, and need to check out the scene in which the writer abused his liver during his Cuban sojourn.

Today, the author of The Old Man and the Sea would probably not set foot in this crowded cash cow, where the rum never stops flowing. But the place is too full of history to skip entirely, so come sip an over-priced mojito, or at least stick your head through the door. And then try one of 14 daiquiris on the menu of Hemingway's other haunt, El Floridita, just a few steps away at Obispo No. 557.

La Bodeguita del Medio

Mojito: around 4 CUC

content.title: Hostal Conde de Villanueva: a cosy break in the old town

introduction.small: Patio, sculptures, and leather: all the pomp of the 18th century in a traditional inn.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hostal Conde de Villanueva: a cosy break in the old town

paragraphs.text:
This large 18th-century house, filled with flowers, was renovated in the 1990s with a colonial-inspired decor, wide brick-coloured paving stones, and comfy leather furniture.

Hostal Conde de Villanueva, an intimate enclave of peace and comfort, has only nine rooms wrapped around a lush green courtyard filled with strutting peacocks. In the suites, the emphasis is on vintage luxury, with stained-glass windows, classical sculptures, and the warm glow of magnificent chandeliers.

There is a bonus for cigar lovers: the inn houses the Casa del Habano, a luxury cigar shop. A traditional torcedor (highly skilled cigar roller) officiates in the lobby, and you can buy fresh cigars from him, made in the purest Havana tradition.

content.title: Castillo de la Real Fuerza: Havana's guardian

introduction.small: This imposing fortress once protected the city from pirates. Its ramparts provide one of the most beautiful views of Havana.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Castillo de la Real Fuerza: Havana's guardian

paragraphs.text:
Built in 1588 by King Philip II of Spain to protect the city from pirates, the Castle of the Royal Force Havana is classified as a UNESCO World Heritage Site. It took African slaves and French prisoners almost 20 years to build this ambitious edifice.

The oldest stone fortress in the Americas, it still commands respect, with its deep moat and impressive ramparts, which offer stunning city views. In 1634, Jerónimo Martin Pinzón decorated its tower with a bronze weathervane in the form of a woman, the famous La Giraldilla, which has since become the symbol of Havana, and graces the label on Havana Club rum bottles.

The monument now houses a maritime museum dedicated to the castle's history and the preservation of the island's naval and underwater archaeological heritage.

Castillo de la Real Fuerza

content.title: Sloppy Joe's: a legendary address for first-rate cocktails

introduction.small: Opened in 1919, this bar was once famous for its… lack of hygiene! The facility has cleaned its kitchen but kept its cachet.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Sloppy Joe's: a legendary address for first-rate cocktails

paragraphs.text:
‘Sloppy Joe' was the nickname given to the first owner of this bar, José Garcia, a young Spanish immigrant renowned for, well, being sloppy. His bar, however, had a solid reputation for friendliness, particularly among the immigrant population of Havana. From 1940-1950, it became a hotspot for starlets and mobsters, who liked to hang out, get drunk, and wolf down Joe's famous sandwich of ropa vieja—stewed beef and crudités.

Destroyed by fire, the bar closed its doors in the 1960s and didn't reopen until 2013.

The new Sloppy Joe's, with its Neoclassical facade, remains faithful to the original, and still offers its famous Sloppy Joe sandwich, matched with a full menu of stunning cocktails.

content.title: Cuban music: baila baila!

introduction.small: There's rumba in air! But before entering one of the temples of Cuban dance, it's best to take a lesson and train your ears and toes.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cuban music: baila baila!

paragraphs.text:
Havana is a giant dance floor. Can't quite get the rhythm? To learn the basic elements or perfect your groove, head straight to the Casa del Son.

The dance school offers group or individual lessons suitable for all levels and the possibility of engaging a partner to try out what you've learned in the warmth of the city's festive nights. Salsa and rumba are integral parts of the island's heritage, but their ubiquity is partly there to satisfy tourists. Cubans dance to an eclectic mix of Spanish reggae, hip-hop, and dancehall.

Many young people like reggaeton, perhaps partially because the government doesn't, while rock, R 'n' B and jazz are well represented at concert halls like the FAC. Stay tuned, don't stay too focussed on clichés, and baila baila!

content.title: Saratoga: Neoclassical luxury

introduction.small: This jewel of the 1930s has been brilliantly modernised and adorned with the dazzling splendour of five stars.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Saratoga: Neoclassical luxury

paragraphs.text:
Located at the intersection of Paseo del Prado and Dragones, the Saratoga overlooks the Capitol. The enfilade of Neoclassical columns on the facade in emerald green, wood, and subtle metalwork immediately sets the tone. This is one of the most popular establishments in the city.

The thaw with the US and the ever-growing appetite of tourists for the island are changing the Cuban hotel industry dramatically, but the Saratoga has been the face of luxury here since its renovation in 2005. It is a showcase of Havana's restoration skills and a portion of its profits goes to safeguarding the heritage of the city centre.

It looks and feels just as it did in the 1930s, when artists and the wealthy jostled at the reception. The rooftop terrace has a pool and a bar and a fabulous view of the hustle and bustle of Havana's seafront esplanade, the Malecón.

content.title: Hang out with Hemingway

introduction.small: Follow in the footsteps of one of the greatest writers of the 20th century for a chic and fanciful journey.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hang out with Hemingway

paragraphs.text:
He liked alcohol, tropical fruits, beautiful women, and fishing. No wonder the famous American writer Ernest Hemingway succumbed to the charms of Cuba. In the 1930s, he regularly stayed in room 511 of the Hotel Ambos Mundos. Left untouched after his departure, the room where he wrote one of his greatest masterpieces, For Whom the Bell Tolls, can now be visited.

A few steps from the hotel, be sure to try the famous daiquiri of the Bodeguita del Medio, a delightfully old-fashioned bar where Hemingway liked to hang out. Sugar, rum, and lemon: this was the novelist's favourite cocktail.

Finally, don't miss the Finca Vigía, the home he acquired in 1939, now a Hemingway museum. To be sure not to miss any stage of your Hemingway pilgrimage, take one of the guided tours.

content.title: El Capitolio: a taste for ostentation

introduction.small: The numbers associated with this marble juggernaut are dizzying and rank it among the most ambitious architectural projects of Havana.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: El Capitolio: a taste for ostentation

paragraphs.text:
Three and a half years of work, more than 5,000 workers, and a total cost of nearly $17 billion: this is what was mobilized for the construction of this giant building decorated with a 62-metre golden dome built entirely of granite and white Capellanía limestone. Nothing was too good for the Cuban Congress, which met in the Capitolio from its inauguration in 1929 until 1959. Ceded to the Cuban Academy of Sciences and the library of science and technology, the monument houses the statue of the Republic, a majestic 17-metre-high bronze covered with gold leaf. Under the dome, the kilometre-zero of all the country's roads is symbolised by a copy of a 24-carat diamond set in the ground.

You can't always visit the interior because of on-going renovations, but you can still admire the magnificence of the outside: roughly 207 meters long, the Capitol is entirely covered with marble.

content.title: Café del Oriente: Havana chic

introduction.small: Tuxedoed waiters and fine food: this gourmet restaurant is one of Havana's most luxurious.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Café del Oriente: Havana chic

paragraphs.text:
Tradition, finesse and high standards are the bywords of this very upmarket establishment, where notables, businessmen, and the most prominent personalities of Havana come together. Inaugurated in 1997 in a historic Neoclassical building in the heart of Havana Vieja, Café del Oriente is spread over two floors.

The ground floor, with its beautiful café-bar, is furnished with club chairs, drapes, and a monumental bar. Upstairs, the divinely elegant five-star restaurant has a gleaming marble floor, velvet chairs, and a grand piano. The ultra-chic room is decorated with a beautiful stained-glass window designed by Cuban artist Rosa Maria de la Terga.

The a la carte menu is distinguished by excellent foie gras, smoked salmon, caviar, and lobster... classic ingredients of impeccable quality.

content.title: Hotel Habana Riviera: back to the 1950s

introduction.small: A former Mafia hangout, this hotel has been relieved of its bad reputation, leaving only the best of its period design…

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel Habana Riviera: back to the 1950s

paragraphs.text:
Inaugurated in 1957, this imposing building, with its classic 1950s glass facade, is a true architectural gem.

Just after its construction, it became a casino, which served as a meeting place for wealthy tourists and local punters, as well as the mob. The casino soon closed, but the hotel kept its vintage design. The gleaming lobby has armchairs in flashy colours, sleek, modernist sculptures, and a marble floor. The 1950s ambiance also reigns in the lobby bar and at the pool. Each of the hotel's 352 rooms is equipped with air conditioning, and the hotel works hard to add maximum comfort and luxury to the vintage spirit.

A perfect spot for modern-art lovers and those nostalgic for post-war Cuba.

content.title: Habana 612: spectacular rehabilitation

introduction.small: Just next to Plaza Vieja, this newly renovated and very exclusive hotel is run by the Office of the City Historian of Havana.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Habana 612: spectacular rehabilitation

paragraphs.text:
This is one of the last jewels rehabilitated by Habaguanex, a company run by the Office of the City Historian of Havana. Named after the native chief who ruled over the territory of Havana at the time of the arrival of Spanish galleons, Habaguanex restores iconic landmarks of Cuban history to accommodate tourists, and then puts the profits back into other restoration projects in the old city centre.

Many of the original elements of the three-storey historical building remain, including stone arches and beautiful stained glass with red and blue accents. These are cleverly juxtaposed with ultra-contemporary furniture and lighting.

The 12 lovely rooms are very comfortable and fully loaded with all the mod-cons, including Wi-Fi and air conditioning. Added benefit of your location: after a wild night of dancing, it is yet impossible to forget the hotel's address… it is all in the name!

content.title: Colon Cemetery: a city within the city

introduction.small: With its gleaming white marble tombs in the shade of palm trees, this cemetery in Havana contains more than 150 years of Cuban history.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Colon Cemetery: a city within the city

paragraphs.text:
Don't search for the tomb of Christopher Columbus in the cemetery that bears his name. It is not there. Built between 1871 and 1886 by the architect Calixto Arellano de Loira y Cardoso, a graduate of the Bellas Artes in Madrid, this is one of the largest cemeteries in the world – 57 hectares of radiating paths interspersed with Rococo and Neoclassical mausoleums and family vaults, with the Central Chapel, modelled after Il Duomo in Florence, at the centre. Reflecting Cuban society, the cemetery is organised into areas, almost like neighbourhoods, according to the status of the occupants: priests, soldiers, aristocrats, the poor, immigrants, atheists... One of the most poignant graves is that of La Milagrosa (The Miraculous), a young woman buried with the body of her new-born at her feet. Legend has it that when the grave was reopened a few years later, the baby had crawled into her mother's arms. Since then, it has become a symbol of hope for anxious mothers and bashful lovers.

content.title: Hotel Meliá Habana: appearances can be deceiving!

introduction.small: Under its austere facade, this hotel hides considerable charms only waiting to be discovered!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel Meliá Habana: appearances can be deceiving!

paragraphs.text:
It looks somewhat daunting, like a dull concrete behemoth. Inside, however, is one of the finest hotels in the city, an establishment full of surprises, starting with its huge lobby enhanced by marble statues and pink paving stones, and decorated with spectacular fountains and elegant jets of water.

As usual in Cuba, designers made it a point of honour to decorate the interiors with enough vegetation to rival the rainforest. But the hotel's highlight is undoubtedly its pool: the largest in the country, it borders the rocky shore of the sea. This is a great place for a family stay: the rooms are comfortable and well air-conditioned, and the staff is helpful.

Ask for a room on the top floors, as they offer breath-taking views of the city or the ocean.

content.title: The beaches: the place for sport and idleness

introduction.small: Whether you prefer sunbathing or kite-surfing, Cuban beaches await you just minutes from the capital.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The beaches: the place for sport and idleness

paragraphs.text:
You only have to drive ten kilometres east of the city to reach Las Playas del Este, a glorious succession of sandy beaches, including Guanabo, El Mégano, Boca Ciega, Guanabo Santa Maria del Mar, and Tarará. The facilities along this nine-kilometre stretch of coastline are sometimes limited but often charming.

Deserted in the winter, this ‘riviera' is crowded with city people in summer, languishing on sunbeds or frolicking in the waves. Pedal boats and towed banana boats are popular, as is surfing and kite-surfing. Cuba Kite Village is a good place for rentals. For a more romantic version, try paddle boarding in the moonlight. And take a long walk along the beach: each beach has its own atmosphere.

content.title: Paladares: paradise of the palate

introduction.small: Take a guided tour through the subtle intricacies of Cuban cuisine at this great table d'hôte, Havana-style.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Paladares: paradise of the palate

paragraphs.text:
The paladares are private restaurants, more or less encouraged by the state, depending on the mood of the regime. They take their name from paladar (palate), the organ of taste. Formerly, only members of the same family could put themselves at the helm of one of these ‘confidential' arrangements.

The rules have eased, but the experience remains just as rich: it's like eating at a friend's, who happens to be an excellent cook with intimate knowledge of the wonders of Cuban cuisine. For an upscale experience, go to Paladar Los Mercades, housed in a historic building.

Prices are higher than in most houses of this type, but the menu and ambience make it worth it: extra refined dishes, both Cuban and international, and, in the background, sweet melodies played on the violin. And just the right special touch: a staircase strewn with flower petals.

content.title: Hotel Nacional de Cuba: history, fame, and pleasure

introduction.small: This architectural gem hosted the biggest names of the 20th century and witnessed Cuba's every historical twist and turn.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel Nacional de Cuba: history, fame, and pleasure

paragraphs.text:
Five stars, eight floors, and 80 years of history: the Hotel Nacional de Cuba is a titan. Built in 1930, it is emblematic of the architecture of the time.

This majestic palace, overlooking the sea, was inaugurated on the evening of 30 December 1930, and the ball given for the occasion has entered the realm of legend. Bombed three years later during a civil revolt, it remained one of the most fabulous hotels in the Americas, a host to stars, billionaires, and heads of state from around the world. It has seen its share of shady characters, too: in the 1950s it was privatized for a Mafia summit!

Now a UNESCO Cultural Heritage Site, it has, since its inauguration, pampered guests in cosy, elegant guest rooms and sublime suites. The pleasant courtyard, where guests eat breakfast, and the sumptuous ballroom only add to the feeling of bygone luxury.

content.title: Café del Angel by Jacqueline Fumero, a tasty concept store

introduction.small: An haute couture café-restaurant in a ready-to-wear shop.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Café del Angel by Jacqueline Fumero, a tasty concept store

paragraphs.text:
In the neo-Gothic shadow of the Holy Guardian Angel Parish, a very unique and peaceful spot in Havana, a no less singular place has opened: the concept store and café of the famous Cuban stylist Jacqueline Fumero.

It serves the best breakfast in the city freshly roasted coffee, eggs, pancakes, the works. It also makes elegant pasta dishes and other attractive offers for travellers tired of the local fare. The clear plastic table and chairs almost disappear among the shop's array of shimmering clothes.

The outdoor furniture combines finely crafted metal and square canvas parasols. A quiet enclave of calm and colour that transports you far from the bustle of the capital.
